title: Tide-Order Questions

quest_giver.name: Senne Vell
quest_giver.affiliation: Order of Knotted Light, Fifth Knot (Exiled Prior)

description: Spray feathered the Pilgrim's Stair like lace, curling over its switchbacks in breaths that smelled of salt, old wax, and prayers kept too long. Lanterns cupped by wind-shy niches threw honey-colored halos that climbed like a second procession beside the living one, and every tread rang with the memory of feet that had climbed to be forgiven or to be refused. Exiled Prior Senne Vell waited by the lion's-mouth spring, where the water's silver thread never thinned, offering salt cakes and a steadiness born of shame faced in full and not turned away from. They asked Neris Quay to guard a quiet parley with Rector Mera, a meeting promised in careful knots and scheduled by the river's breath, where questions must be asked in tide-order—low, slack, high, slack—or the Stair would answer with a bad omen no priest could smooth. Zealots with wrists furred by hard-used cords had begun to police even the shape of a question, and hands were ready with knives for any bridge that tried to span a schism. The Fifth Knot's return could mend a tear that had made every oath-cord in Avarinth sing thin, yet the city had learned to survive by untying itself when the water rose, and now it had to learn what to keep tied. Even the stone felt the weight of it underfoot, a thrum like a hinge before a storm, asking softly with each echoing step which vows should bind a city that has learned to live by letting go and holding fast in the same heartbeat.
objectives: Escort Senne Vell from the hidden landing to a mid-stair niche without zealot interference.
Keep to tide-order Q&A with Rector Mera to soothe the Stair’s superstition and avoid a bad omen.
Retrieve a stolen cord from a zealot cell intent on humiliating the Fifth Knot during the parley.
Help tie a provisional reconciliation knot that hums truth when brought near Parliament lamps.
Ensure the return route remains unobserved by rival factions.

dialogue.speaker: Senne Vell
dialogue.lines: The lamps have long memories, and so do those who tend them, and I have learned which lights I mistook for stars and which were merely reflections on water. Exile taught me to tell the difference between scaffolds that let us build and cages that only keep us standing still, and I have stood very still for too many winters. I do not ask for triumph tonight; I ask for a question to be heard all the way to its end without a fist, a glare, or a doctrine closing over it like a lid. Walk beside me as if you were only a shadow, but let it be a shadow that knows how to stand where a blade wants to land, a shadow that has learned the angles of mercy. If the Stair hums approval, you may feel it through your boots as a low and kindly thunder, and if it does not, we will feel the cold of our own stubbornness and try again with better grace.

dialogue.speaker: Rector Mera
dialogue.lines: I will not pretend I did not dread this meeting, Senne, because dread wears the face of pride when it lingers, and pride is a tighter knot than most novices ever manage on their first day. We both kept the lamps through storms, but we counted their hours differently, and in our counting we cut the city in two, making a ledger of devotion when what it needed was a bridge. The city requires a law stiff enough to brace the flood and a mercy flexible enough to bend with those who run because their hearts demand it, and I admit we lost the balance when fear made us rigid. Neris Quay, keep our circle unbroken with your eyes and with the quiet language of your bow, because there will be those who try to answer our questions with steel and slogans rather than with order and listening. We will ask in tide-order, because the Stair is old and its superstitions have become the habits of many hearts, and while I would not worship a superstition, I will not court an omen that sends pilgrims whispering of doom. If the stolen cord is brought to shame us, we will not return shame with shame; we will reclaim it and tie it to truth in front of every lamp that can bear witness.

dialogue.speaker: Zealot of the Purist Knot
dialogue.lines: The Stair has room for truth, but not for traitors who mistake compromise for compassion and call surrender a sacrament. You come here to untie a penance only because the city has learned to love its own bending more than its backbone, as if every storm were an excuse to throw down the gate and feel the rush of being carried. Our wrists wear cords that cut when we break our promises, and we would rather bleed than barter the knots that kept this city steady when its founders were still bailing grave-water from their shoes. We will not watch the Fifth Knot crawl back under a rain of candles to bind a weaker law and call it reconciliation while the dye-merchants count votes in saffron and ochre. Turn away now, or be numbered with the compromisers when the lamps burn white for judgment, because the white flame does not blink, and it will not be charmed by talk of tides and tenderness.

dialogue.speaker: Neris Quay
dialogue.lines: I have stood on hinges that sing when storms roll in, and I have watched a rope hold a barge whose owner was praying to every god but gravity, and in that song I learned the difference between noise and signal. A good knot is not a prison; it is a promise with room to breathe, and it is no insult to truth to loosen a turn and retie so that the load shares evenly. Wind and water argue all day, yet a well-made cord keeps its shape not by choking but by remembering what it was tied for, and that is a lesson both oaths and cities can afford to relearn. Ask your questions in the right order, and I will keep anyone from answering with knives or with shouts that only sound like courage, because the Stair listens for cadence as much as for content. If a stolen cord is dangled like a noose to shame the Fifth Knot, I will take it back as cleanly as an arrow takes a line across a canal, and I will return it to the hands that know how to tie without strangling.

dialogue.speaker: Senne Vell
dialogue.lines: Let this cord be provisional and public, a visible promise bound to a patience that will not be mistaken for weakness. Let it hum when falsehood leans too close, not to expose with cruelty but to warn the speaker that their tongue has outrun their conscience, so that truth can be caught before it falls. If we are to return, it will be by the same steps we left, with our heads not lowered in meekness but kept level so we can see the faces of those who still doubt and earn their trust with our conduct. A city of lamps deserves a church not afraid of light, and we will not hide our tying behind curtains or in back rooms thick with incense and ambition. Neris, walk our return route as if the air itself had ears, and test each turning for watchers, because reconciliation that begins unobserved has a better chance of growing strong before the jealous hands of factions try to prune it back.

choices.title: Shadow the Parley
choices.text: You choose to escort Senne Vell by water to the hidden landing, keeping the boat's keel in the lion's-mouth spring outflow so the current disguises your wake and swallows stray sounds. On the stairs you drift from niche to niche like a moving gap between lantern halos, letting pilgrims pass through your absence rather than around your presence. You time each pause with the Stair's own breathing—low, slack, high, slack—so questions can be asked in tide-order while the superstitious watchers relax by habit, their vigilance softened by ceremony. A rook-call from Skyline, three streets distant, marks the moment when the zealots pass their satchel with the stolen cord, and you answer with a mirror flick that looks like a stray candle's catch to anyone not trained to read. When the zealots' backs turn to police a pilgrim's phrasing, you slip your hand through stone-shadow and lift the satchel with a hook-finger's grace, palming the cord while leaving a coil of harmless hemp behind, and no one feels the subtraction until the parley is already in motion.
choices.outcome: The parley proceeds in clean segments that click into place like hinge-teeth, each question stepping down to the next without grinding, and the Stair answers with a bass hum that seems to rise more from the stone than from the lamps. Rector Mera and Senne Vell speak with a solemnity unharmed by spectacle, and the hum deepens when they agree to bind a provisional reconciliation knot that will be tested within sight of Parliament lamps. The stolen cord you reclaimed proves to be stained with a faint, telltale bloom of Dyers' Spiral residue; when warmed by your palm the scent of gloam's bitter skin ghosts the air, confirming smug handling and a warehouse origin. Zealots search for their missing theater and find only their certainty, which is a poor prop against silence; their wrath turns inward, and while they vow to try again, they lack proof this night and so the Stair keeps its peace. You thread Senne and Mera back along an unlit return, sticking to spray-dark corners and undercut turns where even the Rookery's mirrored eyes glance off, and the reconciliationists sleep easier knowing a bridge was set without trumpets to draw thieves to its tollbox.

choices.title: Face the Knots
choices.text: You decide to meet the zealots on the stair's open face, stepping between their cord-bruised wrists and the pilgrims they police, and you speak loud enough that lantern-keepers pause their wicks to listen. You invoke tide-law and vow-law with equal precision, naming the Stair's tradition not as a weapon for censure but as a cadence that keeps hot blood from drowning the meaning of a question. When a zealot spits that compromise is cowardice, you answer with the story of a barge held by a rope that had been re-tied in kindness instead of pride, and how that re-tying saved grain enough to keep Lowwater from eating inkroot paste for a month. You then demand, in the order the Stair prescribes, that Rector Mera and Senne Vell ask and answer in low, slack, high, slack, and you hold the rhythm with a slow, steady beat of your boot on stone. When a second zealot flourishes the stolen cord like a banner of shame, you raise your empty hands and ask them to bring it forward under the white lamps so that all can see its dye-bloom and learn the truth of its journey, and the crowd's curiosity becomes your ally like a current catching a skiff by the stern.
choices.outcome: The confrontation becomes a lesson that even the zealots cannot quite refuse, and the Stair's hum wavers toward approval as the questions fall into their proper tide-order despite the heat in everyone's cheeks. Rector Mera speaks of steadfastness that is not tyranny, and Senne Vell admits to errors that were meant as guardrails but became walls, and the crowd nods because their own lives contain such errors too. The zealots, forced into the light they profess to love, offer the stolen cord and sneer until your gloved thumb lifts a faint saffron sheen from a knot's belly; Dyers' Spiral whispers back through the color with its telltale smell, and murmurs ripple outward as people realize someone meant to stage a humiliation rather than reveal a truth. The reconciliation knot is tied in full view to a chorus of held breaths, and when it hums near the lamps the sound is not a shout but a low, trustworthy purr, like a river slipping past a well-set quay. You guide the return not through total shadow but through a tide of goodwill created by the public dignity of the exchange, and while rival factions now know something happened, they have too few sharp edges to catch hold of without cutting themselves on the night's decency.

choices.title: Borrow a Storm
choices.text: You choose to orchestrate a distraction with borrowed signals, tapping an old favor with Gantrix Pell so that a brief, harmless hinge-test murmurs across Chainreach at the same hour as the parley. The signal-lanterns blush with low-grade amber as if a gust had kissed the gantries, and the Stair's attendants glance westward by instinct, their attention tugged like flags to a breeze. In that pause, you angle a mirrorglass flash through a pilgrim's ewer so it breaks into harmless glitter on the steps, a prismatic rain that makes laughter rise where suspicion would normally crouch. While eyes chase the spark-play, you slip into the zealot cell's shadow-niche, where their satchel waits beneath an oath plaque, and you exchange the stolen cord for an identical coil laced with moth-drawing moon-resin dust that will later distract their sentries at a crucial moment. You return to the circle as if you had never left, settling your breath to the tide-order count so the questions land in their appointed places, and you keep your shoulders loose like a bow unstrung by choice rather than by fear.
choices.outcome: The engineered commotion washes over the Stair like a mild squall that cleans the air, and by the time the attention of zealots and pilgrims flows back, the parley has already set its rhythm, making interruption feel like stepping onto a moving deck. Rector Mera and Senne Vell knot their provisional reconciliation cord without spectacle, and when it is brought near a ward-lamp the hum it gives off is small but steady, a tone that settles the stomach rather than thrills it. Later, when zealots discover their satchel's switch, a bloom of moths erupt at their doorway, turning their anger into flailing embarrassment under the wings, and their plan to parade the stolen cord becomes a farce smelled of moon-resin dust. You note, from a corner where wind and rumor like to meet, the faint saffron sigil left in the fibers of the original cord, a Dyers' Spiral stain no rain will wash, and you file the knowledge where it will do the most good without turning into gossip. The return route glides beneath the notice of both the Rookery's mirrors and the Parliament's watchers, but the cost of your borrowed storm is a favor still owed to signals and their keepers, and you feel that debt perch on your shoulder like a rook that expects to be fed.

rewards.description: Blessed oath-cord with three deliberate uses, braided in pearl-white and moon-resin filaments; it hums faintly near deliberate untruths and stills when words return to honesty.
Order escort token for Pilgrim's Stair during feast nights, granting unimpeded passage along prayer-niches and safe harbor at the lion's-mouth spring.
Reconciliationist trust within the Order of Knotted Light; priests and laybinders inclined to hear you first and tie with you second.
Forensic detail: the zealots’ stolen cord bears dye residues from Dyers’ Spiral warehouses—specifically a gloam-adjacent saffron bloom that suggests Compact-linked handling.
